Proofs: getting started with a proof in trigonometry

It is very important when you work out a "proof" (or "show that") question that you feel that you can take a first step: sometimes starting the question is the most difficult part! This question will focus on the first step, not the entire proof.

Useful advice when trying to complete a proof is to start with the more complex side of the equation and simplify it while you leave the other side of the equation untouched!

For the question:

Show that: −2=−1−cos−2(𝑥)+tan2(𝑥)Show that: −2=−1−cos−2⁡(x)+tan2⁡(x)

  1. Which side is the best to work on?

    Answer: It is best to work on .

  2. What is the best first step for this proof from these choices?

    1. change sin2(𝑥)sin2⁡(x) into [1−cos2(𝑥)][1−cos2⁡(x)]

    2. change cos2(𝑥)cos2⁡(x) into [1−sin2(𝑥)][1−sin2⁡(x)]

    3. change sin(2𝑥)sin⁡(2x) into [2sin(𝑥)cos(𝑥)][2sin⁡(x)cos⁡(x)]

    4. use one of the double angle idenities for cos(2𝑥)cos⁡(2x)

    5. change tan(𝑥)tan⁡(x) into sin(𝑥)cos(𝑥)sin⁡(x)cos⁡(x)

    6. multiply the fraction by 1−cos(𝑥)1−cos(𝑥)1−cos⁡(x)1−cos⁡(x)

    7. multiply the fraction by 1+cos(𝑥)1+cos(𝑥)1+cos⁡(x)1+cos⁡(x)

    8. multiply the fraction by 1−sin(𝑥)1−sin(𝑥)1−sin⁡(x)1−sin⁡(x)

    9. multiply the fraction by 1+sin(𝑥)1+sin(𝑥)1+sin⁡(x)1+sin⁡(x)

    10. collect the like terms

    11. factorise part of the expression

    12. simplify immediately by cancelling

    Answer: The best first step is: .
